faq.question: asus chromebook  Will this run photoshop elements 14?
faq.answer: No, I don't think so. It runs the ChromeOS, and AFAIK Photoshop Elements only runs on Mac or Windows. Plus, it's designed for web access and doesn't have a lot of RAM, which you'd want for photo editing

faq.answer: This unit has an Intel Dual-Core Celeron N3060 1.6GHz with it's Intel HD graphics. ASUS Support Manufacturer · April 11, 2018

faq.question: asus chromebook  Does this chrome book comes with word?
faq.answer: No. Chromebooks are web-based computers, so you have to run everything through Google's Chrome web browser. You can access MS Word through the web though. Or you can use Google Docs, which lets you edit MS Word documents and share them again. This is a good summary: http://www.laptopmag.com/articles/chromebook-buying-advice Alfred Baron · December 11, 2016

faq.question: asus chromebook  Will the 802.11.ac wireless compatibility work with an older router?
faq.answer: As long as it is a wireless router, yes. It would be backward compatible to 802.11 legacy / a / b / g and n Peter Laabs · October 10, 2018

faq.question: asus chromebook  What is the estimated year span?
faq.answer: Chromebooks have guaranteed update support for 6.5 years from the first launch for a new hardware platform (which could mean less time for a particular Chromebook, if it is launched later than the first Chromebook to use that hardware). It's also based on the date the platform was first released, so - if you buy an old… see more Chromebooks have guaranteed update support for 6.5 years from the first launch for a new hardware platform (which could mean less time for a particular Chromebook, if it is launched later than the first Chromebook to use that hardware). It's also based on the date the platform was first released, so - if you buy an older Chromebook that has been on the market for 6 years, let's say, you'll only have 6 months of support left. The auto update policy for Chrome OS can be found here: https://support.google.com/chrome/a/answer/6220366?hl=en. This can be really frustrating because the hardware isn't necessarily obsolete. For example, I own both an original Chromebook Pixel and the first Samsung Chromebox. They both have Pentium Core processors and plenty of RAM and SSD, but both have been dropped from updates. Contrary to what others have said in answer to this question, none of my now obsolete devices have continued to receive updates and you can't force an update because there are no new images for those particular boards. Since some of the missed updates have been pretty important - like the Meltdown and Spectre patches - I no longer use those devices. I guess you can think of it this way: You're leasing a Chromebook for 6.5 years and then it will be a paperweight. The upside is that you can install a linux distribution on some of the newer Chrome OS devices and keep them up to date that way, but they will no longer be a Chromebook at that point. see less Chromebooks have guaranteed update support for 6.5 years from the first launch for a new hardware platform (which could mean less time for a particular Chromebook, if it is launched later than the first Chromebook to use that hardware). It's also based on the date the platform was first released, so - if you buy an older Chromebook that has been on the market for 6 years, let's say, you'll only have 6 months of support left. The auto update policy for Chrome OS can be found here: https://support.google.com/chrome/a/answer/6220366?hl=en. This can be really frustrating because the hardware isn't necessarily obsolete. For example, I own both an original Chromebook Pixel and the first Samsung Chromebox. They both have Pentium Core processors and plenty of RAM and SSD, but both have been dropped from updates. Contrary to what others have said in answer to this question, none of my now obsolete devices have continued to receive updates and you can't force an update because there are no new images for those particular boards. Since some of the missed updates have been pretty important - like the Meltdown and Spectre patches - I no longer use those devices. I guess you can think of it this way: You're leasing a Chromebook for 6.5 years and then it will be a paperweight. The upside is that you can install a linux distribution on some of the newer Chrome OS devices and keep them up to date that way, but they will no longer be a Chromebook at that point. Dan Stormont · October 14, 2018

faq.question: asus chromebook  warranty says warning may contain chemicals known to state of ca to cause cancer. should i be concerned?
faq.answer: Everything sold in California May cause cancer. In order for someone to sell a product in California that statement is required even though there is no proof cancer can happen from the product. Phillip T · July 27, 2019

faq.answer: So that's a very good question! Google play and a bunch of other apps are available for this chromebook but the difference is when you launch one of these apps like Spotify or YouTube, it takes you to the web browser. So there is little to no offline capability for this chromebook. But to summarize the answer, as long … see more So that's a very good question! Google play and a bunch of other apps are available for this chromebook but the difference is when you launch one of these apps like Spotify or YouTube, it takes you to the web browser. So there is little to no offline capability for this chromebook. But to summarize the answer, as long as you have Internet, you definitely have access to google play. see less So that's a very good question! Google play and a bunch of other apps are available for this chromebook but the difference is when you launch one of these apps like Spotify or YouTube, it takes you to the web browser. So there is little to no offline capability for this chromebook. But to summarize the answer, as long as you have Internet, you definitely have access to google play. Nathaniel · December 22, 2016
